TLINE.TDLINE: &USE&
The gicom organizational model enables the mapping of both the company
structure and article organization of a trade company. In the following,
the gicom organizational model for a business organization is described.
Via customizing the required business organization for the gicom
organizational structure from the perspective of the negotiation and
settlement management can be defined. This organization initially
consists of organizational units which are used in the general business
of the company - "real organizational units". "Virtual organizational
units" can be maintained as well, which are the organizational units
that possibly are only needed within the scope of the Agreements
management - for example, the grouping of regional markets for shared
promotional activities.
Accordingly, an organizational unit may represent any business unit,
such as a purchase organization, company code, and factory or in the
case of the article model also a product hierarchy.
To map all kinds of agreements, the fields Sender and Receiver are used
as dimensions. Sender and Receiver can be organizational units or
business partners (Suppliers and Customers), to be able to create
different scenarios where agreements at different levels are granted.
The company structure of a company is displayed by internal / static
organizational units. They may but do not always represent a business
object, because also “virtual" levels such as regions are concerned.
For the simplification of the sender/receiver logic, each business
partner, supplier and customer receives an orgID. These are the
so-called external / dynamic organizational units. This occurs
automatically at the background.
&PRECONDITIONS&
&STANDARD_SETUP&
&ACTIVITY&
Step1: Organizational levels
As a first step for the mapping of a gicom organizational structure the
gicom organizational levels must be defined. A level is defined by
several general attributes, which can be found in the different
organizational units. This way, the organizational units which are
classified as a "market" are identified with different names and
addresses, but they have the same attributes regarding product sales to
the end customer, they have one manager and they have one accounting
unit.
Therefore, you must first define the required types of organizational
levels, before the organizational units can be defined.
Step 2: New creation of organizational levels
The organizational levels can be maintained in the view cluster
maintenance /GICOM/VC_TORG.
The following attributes need to be maintained for every organizational
level:
Level defines the priority of the respecting level. The highest-level
needs to have the lowest number, e.g. the level “all articles” has level
1. All other levels can be set into a hierarchy through the allocation
of corresponding numbers, which means the next lower level gets the
number 2 etc.
Organizational level
Title the title of the organizational level
Type indicates whether the organizational level and later the
corresponding unit is a
Article group (internal)
Organizational unit (internal)
Business partner (external)
Step 3: Allocation rules of the organizational structure
Per the definition of the organizational levels there must be rules
defined for their allocation. These assignments determine the future
structure of an organizational unit and the relationship they may have
with other organizational units.
The allocation rules are defined by putting the pre-defined
organizational classes in relation. For this purpose, each possible
relation between the respective organizational levels is created once.
It should be considered that not only direct but also all indirect
connection rules need to apply. This means that a class "goods group",
the direct parent of which is the "main goods group", depends indirectly
on the parent "main goods group", the "section", as well as on the
parent thereof, etc.
Example for the Formation of an Organizational Structure
To define which assignment are possible, the table column under the
definition of the organizational levels is used.
To maintain a connection between two levels, you need to highlight the
level which will be the parent in the new connection. After highlighting
the level, you can switch into the subordinate column “Organizational
level hierarchy” and enter the respective child. The level ID of the
child, the validity period and the priority need to be entered. Priority
and ID need to be correspondent.
Step 4: Organizational units
A gicom organization of the company structure consists of a network of
real organizational units, each of which belongs to a specific
organizational level and which are related to each other. Each
organizational unit is a manifestation of an organizational level - in a
way that it may represent a market which is allocated to a company code
Next to this market there may be many different markets N003, N004, etc.
- which all will be identified as gicom organizational level "market".
Also, other organizational levels exist, such as "national subsidiary"
and "sales channel", which all are again identified as a real
organizational unit, such as national subsidiary "Netherlands" or sales
channel "XY market".
Finally, the organizational units are related to each other. This
includes mandatory relations such as "A market is allocated to a sales
channel" and "A national subsidiary is allocated to the holding", but
also optional relations such as "A market can be allocated to a group".
For the maintenance of organizational units, the organizational model,
the organizational levels, the organizational assignments and the
organizational units - customizing must be considered.
The organizational units are created via the view cluster maintenance
/GICOM/VC_TORG.
View cluster maintenance organizational units
For the new definition of an organizational unit, the following fields
must be completed:
Type the object type of the organizational unit. The possibilities are:
Organizational unit (internal)
Article unit (internal)
Business partner (external)
Object ID: This field displays the key of the organizational unit that
was assigned automatically.
Title: Here you enter the name of the organizational unit, which will be
used in the agreement maintenance.
Valid from: Start date of the validity period of the organizational
unit. In the initial state this is the date of creation. If within the
scope of an organizational change the master data of an organization are
changed and a new version is created the required version can be
selected with help of the "Valid from" date.
Valid to: Start date of the validity period of the organizational unit.
In the initial condition the date 31/12/9999, which corresponds to an
unlimited period.
Agreements allowed: If agreements can be created for this organizational
unit, this feature must be activated.
Authority of negotiation: If the organizational unit is an authority of
negotiation, the checkbox must be ticked.
Range of validity: If the organizational unit is a range of validity,
the checkbox must be ticked and a representative company code must be
entered.
Representative C Code: If the organizational unit is defined as a range
of validity, the entry of a representative company code is required.
BO Type: In this field the business object type is defined. This may be
a company code, a product group, a purchase organization etc.
BO ID: In this field, you enter the concrete business object, i.e. an
object ID of the pre-selected type which should be used in this context.
If a product group was selected previously, enter in this field the ID
of the specific product group which is obtained about this
organizational unit.
Step4.1: Organizational unit hierarchy
As described previously, all organizational units form a hierarchy. To
display this hierarchy, you must allocate the subordinated units to the
higher units. Each allocation will be provided with a priority, in which
the lowest number represents the highest priority, thus the highest
level of a company hierarchy.
To illustrate this: the highest knot is initially assigned to itself and
then all subordinated units are allocated to it. When the highest level
is "ALL" while the national subsidiaries are below it, these
subsidiaries will all be allocated to upper knot. All these assignments
are now provided with the same lowest priority, for example 1. In the
next step, regions are allocated to the national subsidiaries. Each
individual company will be assigned with the subordinated regions and
its own knot. Furthermore, all these connections will be assigned with
the next priority, for example 2. The process continues until the lowest
level is reached.
The hierarchy can be created in the SM34 view cluster maintenance
/GICOM/VC_TORG. Here, the needed organizational unit must be
highlighted, and you can either choose the subordinate column “assigned
parents” or “assigned children”. Here, you can maintain the children and
parents of the chosen organizational unit.
Assigned parents / children
In the column “assigned parents” you can enter the parents of the chosen
unit, the relation type, the valid from date and the priority. The same
applies for the maintenance of the children of an organizational unit.
Step4.2 Authorities of negotiation, ranges of validity and their
assignment
An organizational unit can have additional features specifying its
properties. These features are "Authority of negotiation" and "Range of
Validity". An Authority of negotiation is an organizational unit for the
negotiation of contracts. An authority of negotiation has the
negotiating competency for one or more ranges of validity. A range of
validity is an organizational unit, for which an agreement can be valid.
To define an organizational unit as a range of validity, it should be
provided with a representative company code. This company code is the
internal legal contract partner via which contracts are concluded for
this range of validity.
The structure of the ranges of validity is the same as the
Organizational structure. An organizational unit is characterized as a
range of validity via the field "Range of Validity".
An organizational area is thus an authority of negotiation, when it is
defined as "Authority of Negotiation".
The territories are placed in a hierarchy in the same way as the
organizational units. This also occurs via the SM34 view cluster
maintenance /GICOM/VC_TORG.
Authority of negotiation
For the authority of negotiation hierarchy, you can highlight a
superordinate unit and determine the subordinate ranges of validity and
article groups.
If you want to assign a range of validity, you highlight an authority of
negotiation and choose the column “Authority of negotiation – assignment
rov” afterwards. Now you can enter a range of validity and a period, for
which the assignment is valid.
The article group can be maintained in the same manner, via highlighting
the chosen authority of negotiation and determining a subordinate
article group.
&EXAMPLE&
